message_1:
Calculate the standard electrode potential of the electrode in the given electrochemical cell: 

Fe3+(aq) + 3e- → Fe(s)                            E°= -0.04V 

Ag+(aq) + e- → Ag(s)                                  E°= 0.80V
message_2:
To calculate the standard electrode potential of the given electrochemical cell, we need to determine the reduction half-reaction and the oxidation half-reaction. The reduction half-reaction is the one with the higher standard reduction potential, and the oxidation half-reaction is the one with the lower standard reduction potential.

In this case, the reduction half-reaction is:
Ag+(aq) + e- → Ag(s)                                  E°= 0.80V

And the oxidation half-reaction is:
Fe3+(aq) + 3e- → Fe(s)                            E°= -0.04V

To calculate the standard electrode potential of the cell, we need to subtract the standard reduction potential of the oxidation half-reaction from the standard reduction potential of the reduction half-reaction:

E°(cell) = E°(reduction) - E°(oxidation)

E°(cell) = 0.80V - (-0.04V)

E°(cell) = 0.80V + 0.04V

E°(cell) = 0.84V

The standard electrode potential of the given electrochemical cell is 0.84V.
